dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A price war between Russia and Saudi Arabia, and suddenly global markets are acting like a pressure cooker that just had its lid blown off.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A price war between Russia and Saudi Arabia, and suddenly global markets are acting like a pressure cooker that just had its lid blown off.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Global stocks plunged after crude oil posted its biggest fall since the 1991 Gulf War after Saudi Arabia launched a price war with Russia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? I mean, the Nikkei in Japan shot up more than 5% on Monday alone. That's a massive jump.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? I mean, the Nikkei in Japan shot up more than five percent on Monday alone. That's a massive jump.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Japans Nikkei index fell more than 5% on Monday, while stocks in Hong Kong and mainland China were also down as panicked investors in Asia flocked to safe-haven assets like government bonds and the Japanese yen.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it wasn't just Asia—London's FTSE 100 was up almost 8%, which is just… staggering for a single morning.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it wasn't just Asia-London's F T S E one hundred was up almost eight percent, which is just... staggering for a single morning.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: European stocks followed suit, with Londons FTSE 100 index down almost 8% on Monday morning, Frances CAC 40 more than 7% and Germanys DAX 6%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and oil prices went wild too. Brent crude hit $43.20 a barrel, and West Texas Intermediate climbed 21% over the weekend.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and oil prices went wild too. Brent crude hit forty three point two zero dollars a barrel, and West Texas Intermediate climbed twenty one percent over the weekend.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Oil prices plummeted with the benchmark Brent crude down to $33.20 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate fell 31%, to $28.32 a barrel on Sunday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's all tied to that breakdown between OPEC and Saudi Arabia, right? Russia deciding to cut production really set this off.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's all tied to that breakdown between O P E C and Saudi Arabia, right? Russia deciding to cut production really set this off.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The steep drop was triggered after Saudi Arabia announced it would raise production after OPEC's deal with Russia to supply collapsed on Friday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And investors seem to be shrugging off a lot of the coronavirus fears, at least for now. They're piling into riskier assets again.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And investors seem to be shrugging off a lot of the coronavirus fears, at least for now. They're piling into riskier assets again.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Japans Nikkei index fell more than 5% on Monday, while stocks in Hong Kong and mainland China were also down as panicked investors in Asia flocked to safe-haven assets like government bonds and the Japanese yen.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Even Australia's market added something like $90 billion in value on Monday. The ASX had its best day since the dot-com bubble.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even Australia's market added something like ninety dollars billion in value on Monday. The A S X had its best day since the dot-com bubble.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some $90 billion ($140 billion AUD) was wiped off Australias markets on Monday, with the benchmark ASX falling more than 7%its worst performance since the global financial crash.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is kind of ironic, because Goldman Sachs is warning oil could still spike to $100 a barrel if the virus situation gets worse and the price war heats up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is kind of ironic, because Goldman Sachs is warning oil could still spike to one hundred dollars a barrel if the virus situation gets worse and the price war heats up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Oil prices could drop to a low of $20 a barrel, Goldman Sachs analysts warned on Sunday, if the coronavirus continues to spread and the oil price war intensifies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that feels like a real possibility. And with the Fed's emergency rate cut earlier this month, there's this weird mix of confidence and uncertainty right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that feels like a real possibility. And with the Fed's emergency rate cut earlier this month, there's this weird mix of confidence and uncertainty right now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Federal Reserves emergency rate on March 3, 2020, provided a momentary confidence boost for the markets, which now will look for coordinated action from the G7 club of advanced economies to underpin the global economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's like everyone's betting on central banks and governments to keep things afloat, but the underlying risks—uh, the virus, the oil volatility—are still very much there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like everyone's betting on central banks and governments to keep things afloat, but the underlying risks-uh, the virus, the oil volatility-are still very much there.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And speaking of the virus, new cases are still rising globally. Italy's dealing with serious clusters now, outside of China.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And speaking of the virus, new cases are still rising globally. Italy's dealing with serious clusters now, outside of China.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some 110,000 people globally have been infected with Covid-19 to date, but as of Monday the number of new cases in China, where the pneumonia-like virus was detected, appear to be falling, while cases around the world continue to prompt strict quarantine measures, particularly in Italy, now the largest cluster of Covid-19-related deaths outside China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which makes this market rally even more surreal. Investors are calm, but the news headlines are anything but.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which makes this market rally even more surreal. Investors are calm, but the news headlines are anything but.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Global stocks plunged after crude oil posted its biggest fall since the 1991 Gulf War after Saudi Arabia launched a price war with Russia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. It's one of those moments where the numbers tell a very different story from what you feel in the air.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. It's one of those moments where the numbers tell a very different story from what you feel in the air.

artist_script:
HostA: A price war between Russia and Saudi Arabia, and suddenly global markets are acting like a pressure cooker that just had its lid blown off.
HostB: Right? I mean, the Nikkei in Japan shot up more than 5% on Monday alone. That’s a massive jump.
HostA: And it wasn’t just Asia—London’s FTSE 100 was up almost 8%, which is just… staggering for a single morning.
HostB: Yeah, and oil prices went wild too. Brent crude hit $43.20 a barrel, and West Texas Intermediate climbed 21% over the weekend.
HostA: It’s all tied to that breakdown between OPEC and Saudi Arabia, right? Russia deciding to cut production really set this off.
HostB: Exactly. And investors seem to be shrugging off a lot of the coronavirus fears, at least for now. They’re piling into riskier assets again.
HostA: Even Australia’s market added something like $90 billion in value on Monday. The ASX had its best day since the dot-com bubble.
HostB: Which is kind of ironic, because Goldman Sachs is warning oil could still spike to $100 a barrel if the virus situation gets worse and the price war heats up.
HostA: Yeah, that feels like a real possibility. And with the Fed’s emergency rate cut earlier this month, there’s this weird mix of confidence and uncertainty right now.
HostB: It’s like everyone’s betting on central banks and governments to keep things afloat, but the underlying risks—uh, the virus, the oil volatility—are still very much there.
HostA: And speaking of the virus, new cases are still rising globally. Italy’s dealing with serious clusters now, outside of China.
HostB: Which makes this market rally even more surreal. Investors are calm, but the news headlines are anything but.
HostA: For sure. It’s one of those moments where the numbers tell a very different story from what you feel in the air.
